explanation:
Brief reason for each symbol needed to determine compliance with the MISRA 'for loop shall be well-formed' rule when analyzing OS_MutSemTake:

- OS_ObjectIdGetById: Called directly by OS_MutSemTake; its implementation must be examined because any for-loops or side effects inside it count as part of the behavior of functions called from within a loop in the caller (MISRA: loop body includes called functions). Also to see whether it modifies objects visible to the caller.
- OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit: Helper used by OS_ObjectIdGetById; include to fully understand any loops/side effects in the ObjectId lookup path.
- OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex: Helper used by OS_ObjectIdGetById; may contain loops or modify shared objects that could interact with for-loop constraints.
- OS_ObjectIdConvertToken: Helper used by OS_ObjectIdGetById; needed to see whether token conversion has side effects or uses/modifies objects that a for-loop clause in the caller must not rely upon.
- OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel: Helper used by OS_ObjectIdGetById; include for completeness to detect any hidden loop behaviour or side effects.
- OS_MutSemTake_Impl: Called directly; must be reviewed because any loops inside it (or modifications it performs) are considered as part of the behaviour when called inside a for statement in the caller. Also it may modify objects that a for-clause is not allowed to use/modify.
- OS_ObjectIndexFromToken: Called by OS_MutSemTake_Impl; include to trace nested behaviour/side-effects reachable from OS_MutSemTake and detect loops or modifications of shared objects.
- OS_TaskGetId: Called directly; its implementation/behaviour must be known because assignment to mutex->last_owner uses its return — if any loop in the caller used that object it could matter. Also TaskGetId may be a wrapper that calls other functions with loops.
- OS_TaskGetId_Impl: Concrete implementation of OS_TaskGetId (may contain loops or side-effects relevant to MISRA analysis).
- OS_OBJECT_TABLE_GET: Macro used to obtain the mutex pointer; its definition must be inspected to ensure it doesn't expand into a for-loop or produce side-effects that would affect the for-loop clause rules (e.g., hidden increments or function calls).
- OS_mutex_internal_record_t: Type definition of the mutex object (needed to know fields, e.g., last_owner) and whether accessing/modifying last_owner could violate 'only one loop counter' or 'objects modified in loop body' constraints.
- OS_object_token_t: Type of token used to index the object table; needed to understand how token is used/modified and whether any for-loop clauses could rely on it or have it modified in called functions.
- OS_SUCCESS: Constant used for return comparisons; include to interpret control flow (which branches execute) when mapping potential loops to behaviour.
- OS_LOCK_MODE_NONE and LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE: Constants passed to OS_ObjectIdGetById; include to understand object lookup mode or type-specific behaviour in the implementation (some implementations vary by mode/type and may include loops or side-effects).

Note: The UT_* stub functions seen in the static call graph are part of the unit-test harness; include them only if you are analyzing a unit-test build where those stubs are actually substituted for implementations. They are omitted here as they are not required for a standard source-level MISRA for-loop analysis of OS_MutSemTake.
